title: In triangle ABC, where AC = 2 and BC = 1, why is 30 degrees the largest angle A can be? - Quora

response.answer_text: There have been geometric answers already, but here is how to power through the calculus. The plan: let [math]x[/math] be the missing side of the triangle. You can see that [math]1\leq x\leq 3[/math]. Get the missing angle [math]A[/math] as a function of [math]x[/math], and then maximize the function on this interval. Step 1: By the Law of Cosines, [math]1^2=2^2+x^2-4x\cos(A)[/math] Step 2: Solve for [math]\cos(A)[/math]: [math]1=4+x^2-4x\cos(A)[/math] [math]\frac{x^2+3}{4x}=\cos(A)[/math] Step 3: We want to maximize [math]A[/math]. Since [math]\cos(A)[/math] is a decreasing function on [math][0,180][/math], which is the set of possible angles in a triangle, this is the same as minimizing [math]\cos(A)[/math]. So find the minimum. Find the derivative: [math]\frac{d}{dx}\frac{x^2+3}{4x}=\frac{4x(2x)-4(x^2+3)}{16x^2}[/math] Set to zero (same as setting the numerator to zero): [math]8x^2-4x^2-12=0[/math] [math]x=\sqrt{3}[/math] This value of [math]x[/math] lies in the desired interval. (The negative root does not.) I will not go through the full check that this is in fact the minimum. Now to find [math]A[/math], use the function found earlier: [math]\frac{x^2+3}{4x}=\cos(A)[/math] Plug in [math]x=\sqrt{3}[/math]: [math]\frac{6}{4\sqrt{3}}=\cos(A)[/math] [math]\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}=\cos(A)[/math] [math]A=30[/math] and we are done.

The largest angle is formed when the angle ACB is 90 degrees. This gives angle CAB 30 degrees. If you draw a point C then get a compass and draw two circles (A, B) with C the centre of radius 2 and 1 respectively. Then try to make a triangle you will see this is the case.
Draw a circle with radius 1 and center C. The largest angle A can obtain is where AB is tangent to the circle. Then ABC is a right angle and CAB is 30 degrees.
if AC > BC then maximum A when B=90°, using sine law A=30°. TrianCal
